theText: I agree with the previous speaker, the honourable memberWednesday, 18 October 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2427 The deal had another price: an ongoing $20 million a year support bill for local mariners. That is what this bill that we are debating today is all about: an ongoing $20 million a year support bill for mariners. Who foots that bill? Who covers the cost that the government is asking us all to commit to today? It is the taxpayers of Australia. The taxpayers of Australia have absolutely been bled dry by the mismanagement of ANL. At the same time, and in the same article, we saw that the minister spent almost $1 million of taxpayers' funds on the you-beaut pair of whiz-kids-the mates-that are supposedly getting ANL out of the mire. They have achieved nothing. The value has gone down. We have not $1 million retainer. They have been paid almost $1 million of taxpayers' money to try and salvage ANL, to get it up and running so that we can sell it and get some profit for Australia for the Australian taxpayers. We have seen nothing. Now we are asked to sign off on a bill that is going to spend almost $20 million a year of taxpayers' money . We must ask the question: on what? It is interesting. What is the purpose of the bill? The purpose of the bill, according to the Bills Digest from the library, is to provide for a system of grants-'grants' is an interesting word to use-to Australian shipowners who undertake international voyages. According to the explanatory memorandum, the grants will: ... place Australian shipowners on a more equal footing with their overseas competitors in respect of crew costs and provide an incentive for the Australian shipping industry to develop new international trading opportunities. When you dig into it a little deeper, what is the money really being spent on? The money is really being spent on the arrangement that was made with the unions earlier this year. In September 1994, the Prime Minister( Mr Keating), senior cabinet ministers, the ACTO and the Maritime Union met to negotiate an industry reform package. As a result of those negotiations, Treasurer Willis announced via a press release on 9 May 1995 that the government had agreed to the introduction of a taxable outlays grant-taxable in the hands of the companies, so that there is company tax payable on it-to be paid to owners and operators of Australian-registered ships predominantly engaged in international trade, to offset the impact on owners and operators of personal income tax on the earnings of seafarers on Australia's eligible international trading ships. The grant is to be administered by the Department of Transport. Subsidising the PAYE tax that is paid by members of the Maritime Union of Australia is what it is all about. The bill goes on to talk about eligibility but, interestingly enough, Australian flag shipping carries only four per cent of Australia's foreign trade, and ANL is not the major carrier of this portion. We are supposedly providing a subsidy, and it is interesting to look at this in terms of the overall public policy direction in which the government is going, as far as subsidies and tariff protection for Australian industry are concerned. Everybody else in this country has had the barriers in front of them tom down by this government. There is no protection. 'Get out there on the world stage and become world competitive: no protection for you!' Australia, as a nation in the international marketplace, has led the way in tariff and subsidy reduction, ahead of any signing of the Uruguay Round. I noted in some of the information I researched to speak on this bill that the Uruguay Round on free trade and 'detariffication' did not get to international transport or international shipping. That was left out. That is all well and good, but this Labor government of Australia has hurtled down the path of 'detariffication', pulling down those barriers which are protective walls for

theText: that is, one Mr Turnbull and one Mr Wran-have been paid their almostMC 2428 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 18 October 1995 a lot of Australian industry. Australian industry has been told, 'You get out there and compete and become world competitive!' Here today, we are heading back in the other direction by providing assistance and a subsidy, in a roundabout fashion. All the commentary on the bill says that it is supposed to make our shipping lines more world competitive. But does not that beg the question of why our shipping lines are not world competitive? Everywhere else, we are expected to be world competitive without any assistance, subsidy or tariffs. Why are they not world competitive? The taxpayers of Australia need to ask that question. The bill is born out of a deal with the Maritime Union of Australia, whereby Minister Brereton wanted things to go along quietly while he was trying to sort out his unbelievable mess with the Australian National Line. As a buy-off as far as that union was concerned, the minister said he was going to provide a subsidy, supposedly to international shipping. But it is all about keeping the union happy, because that is where it is ending up. It is going to the companies, but it is ending up back with the unions. Fair enough! But let us be fair about the whole thing. We say to our primary producers and manufacturing industries, 'Get out there and compete on the world stage, without any assistance from this government.' This is one of the reasons that our primary industries cannot compete: they have had their hands tied by the lack of true micro-economic reform as far as the transport industry is concerned. We have seen the decisions that this government has made as far as tearing down those tariff barriers and subsidy mechanisms is concerned. In its haste to be one of the gang and one of the big players on the world market as far as free trade is concerned, Australia has led the way. We have pulled down our tariff levels and then we have gone off and signed up in the Uruguay Round of the GA'IT to reduce them by a percentage each year, starting from a lower base than everybody else is on. I am yet to be convinced that, in that area, we are ever going to end up on a footing level with some of our competitors around the world, because we are starting low and coming down, while they are starting up high. The most salient point is that we are telling all our other industries in Australia to go out and become more efficient, ,to become more effective, to become better producers and to compete on the world stage, yet we are not asking this industry to compete. We are not asking this industry to have a close look at itself and ask itself why it cannot compete. What are we doing? We are providing the industry with a subsidy which is going to end up back at the level that I spoke of earlier, on the premise that it is going to make this industry more world competitive. Do you know what? It will not. It will not work. It never has. And it never will work, for the same reasons that we have had to make all our primary industries, all our manufacturing industries, cut the fat, get rid of the fat, have a close look at their process and work out why they really are not competitive. It did not work there and now those industries are competing, not because of anything the government has done but because they have had a long, hard look at their process and they have found ways and means to become more world competitive. There is a long way to go in that area, where a future government might be able to help them. But this measure by this government will not go anywhere near helping the shipping lines become more world competitive. Of course some of the industry organisations are going to agree. They are getting a handout. That has never helped anybody get off their butt and go and compete and make themselves productive and efficient. It just will not work. History will prove this government wrong in putting this bill before the parliament today and asking us to sign off on it. Wednesday, 18 October 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2429 On that basis, the opposition is not going to sign off on it. We are going to oppose this bill because it is not right. It is heading in the opposite direction from what this government is expecting of most other industries in this country. On that basis we are going to oppose it. As I say, history will record that this government is heading in the wrong direction and that this sort of measure will not achieve what it is designed to do in helping the shipping industry to be more competitive. The government knows where it has to head to to make Australian shipping more competitive and this is not that direction. I think that it is important that these comments be recorded and that the government be made aware that, as I said before, it is not fooling the people in the press gallery, it is not fooling the people that are informing the people of Australia on what is going on. I will just repeat the comments of Laura Tingle, because I think they are just a classic. I used this in a speech when we were debating the ANL Sale Bill a couple of weeks ago. I do not know that Laura Tingle is really a great fan of the coalition either, but her headline was, 'Labor's behaviour in flogging our shipping line has been disgraceful.' In part of that article she said, 'The deal had another price: an ongoing $20 million a year support bill for local mariners.' That puts it in a nutshell. It is nothing to do with making Australian shipping more competitive. It is a $20 million a year support bill for local mariners, and it is a disgrace. As she said, the behaviour of the Labor Party in flogging the Australian shipping line has been disgraceful. The coalition will oppose this bill. Employment, Education and Training) (12.39 p.m.}-It is my happy duty to sum up on this debate. I was parliamentary secretary to the minister for transport some years ago and I think the member for Hume( Mr Sharp) was then the shadow minister. He is still the shadow minister and I do not think he has learnt a great deal over that time. WhatI am astounded by is his absolute lack of regard for the reforms that have already taken place in the Australian shipping industry, which seem to be ignored totally by the opposition, and the rather gratuitous advice they seem to be giving the Australian community about the way in which the shipping industry is performing. It is worth contemplating, as the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister (Dr Theophanous) outlined in the second reading speech, just one aspect of the reform process which has taken place. In 1983 a typical Australian trading ship had a crew of 33. The opposition would have us believe that nothing has changed since 1983. Has something changed? Has it or has it not? Have we improved the crew rates on Australian flag vessels? Simple answer, yes or no. Answer-yes. We will not hear of opposition members saying to the community that the reform measures activated by this government-not by a coalition government-have not had a dramatic impact on crew rates. When the coalition was in government before 1983 and when we came into government in that year the figure was 33. What is it today? Do you know the answer? Eighteen. Do you think that is some improvement? Do you think it might be just a marginal improvement, or do you think it is a dramatic improvement? were well in excess of OECD levels; today our crew levels are lower.

Of the three major components to this bilI, the one which seems to have incurred the ire of the opposition concerns the grants that are payable, based on the tax liabilities of seafarers in Australia's international trading ships. I am not going to canvass all of the issues in this debate but, to have some integrity in public life, you could surely accept that, even though you may not agree with everything the government does-and I do not expect you ever will-you might at some stage accept that there has been dramatic improvement, dramatic micro-economic reform, in the shipping industry in Australia and that this bill is part of that reform process. If you were genuinely interested in competitive shipping for Australia, you would acknowledge that. But we do not hear any acknowledgment of it; all we hear are disparaging comments about these shipping industry reforms and disparaging comments about the Minister for Industrial Relations ( Mr Brereton). Both views are out of order because the shipping industry supports these reforms. As shadow minister you do not support them but the shipping industry does, and if you were in touch with your shadow portfolioI had to remind the honourable member for Hume earlier in the debate, to be judicious and careful with his use of the word 'you'Speaker. minister-who actually lives very close to Canberra, I might say, and not very close to the sea-needs to be aware that these reforms are supported by the shipping industry. If it is not the waterfront, it is the shipping industry we continue to hear about, which amazes me.
